titleStmt.title: Investigation of phase-transformation path in TiZrHf(VNbTa)x refractory high-entropy alloys and its effect on mechanical property

affiliation.orgName: Faculty of Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials Engineering
Department of Materials Science and Engineering

analytic.title: Investigation of phase-transformation path in TiZrHf(VNbTa)x refractory high-entropy alloys and its effect on mechanical property

biblStruct.note: Received 17 May 2021 Received in revised form 9 July 2021 Accepted 13 July 2021

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: High entropy alloys Refractory alloys Bo-Md parameter Phase transformation Work hardening

div.p: Refractory high-entropy alloys (RHEAs) show a great potential as structural materials due to their remarkable properties, such as high strength and thermal stability. Despite these advantages, the RHEAs still suffer from the limited ductility at room temperature. To overcome the strength-ductility trade-off, the new RHEA design strategy, transformation-induced plasticity (TRIP) HEAs, have been developed by applying metastability-engineering approach. With the newly developed RHEAs design strategy, we designed metastable RHEAs, TiZrHfVxNbxTax (x = 1.0, 0.5 and 0.1) with decrease of the β-stabilizing elements (V, Nb, and Ta) to promote the transformation-induced ductility and work-hardening capability. The proper addition of the β-stabilizing elements (V, Nb, and Ta) into the ternary equi-molar TiZrHf alloy (TiZrHfV 0.1 Nb 0.1 Ta 0.1 ) leads to stress/strain-induced phase transformation from the body-centered cubic (BCC) to hexagonalclose-packed (HCP) α′ and/or orthorhombic α″ phases. Detailed studies on the phase transformation sequence during the deformation were carried out using X-ray diffraction (XRD), electron back-scattered diffraction (EBSD), and transmission-electron microscope (TEM), which revealed the stepwise phase transformation that is responsible for the strong strain hardening behavior. Furthermore, we further suggested the new transformation-induced-plasticity (TRIP) HEA design strategy, applying the Bo-Md approach.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Refractory high-entropy alloys (RHEAs), which consist of more than 4 principal refractory elements and forming a single bodycentered cubic (BCC) solid solution, have received a great attention due to their high yield strength, and excellent softening resistance during high-temperature deformations [1][2][3]. These excellent mechanical properties have motivated tremendous efforts to design and study on single solid-solution phase HEAs. Recently, new HEA design strategies have been developed by experimental efforts and theoretical approaches to further improve the mechanical properties, such as precipitation-hardened HEAs [4], multi-phase HEAs [5], and twinning-induced plasticity (TWIP)/ transformation-induced plasticity (TRIP) HEAs [6,7]. Especially, TRIP HEAs have attracted extensive attentions, owing to their excellent room temperature ductility, which is still great challenge in HEA research fields for practical applications [8,9]. TRIP effects in alloys such as TRIP steels and metastable Ti alloys are generated by phase-transformations during plastic deformation, resulting in improved combinations of strength and ductility [10,11]. For example, the metastable BCC phase in Ti-4Al-4Fe-0.25Si-0.1O alloys tends to transform to the martensite α′ (stable phase) through stress/strain-induced phase-transformation, presenting 1340 MPa of UTS and 30% of fracture strain [12]. Beyond the conventional Ti-alloys, the FCC-structured Fe 80-x Mn x Co 10 Cr 10 HEAs indicate the enhanced strength and ductility by reducing the Mn elements [9]. The decreasing of Mn contents gives rise to destabilizing the FCC phase, which efficiently promotes the TRIP effect by stress/strain-induced phase transformation from FCC to HCP during plastic deformation. Moreover, Haung et al. [11], have applied similar alloy design approach, i.e., metastability-engineering, in brittle BCC-type Ta x HfZrTi RHEAs to improve the room temperature ductility via tailoring the stability of the constituent phases, workhardening capability, and TRIP effect. The TaHfZrTi RHEA shows the single BCC phase with brittle mechanical characteristic, whereas the HCP phase is produced and gradually increased as the Ta contents reduced from 16.7 to 11.8 at%, indicating that formation of BCC phase is suppressed but that of HCP phase is promoted by decreasing of the β-stabilizing Ta elements. As decrease of Ta elements, the ductility is significantly improved from 4% to 30.6%, which is mainly originated from the TRIP effect (phase-transformation from destabilized-BCC to HCP phase). This previously reported study further suggested that the metastability-engineering strategy provides multiple benefits for strength, such as microcomposite-effect-induced strengthening and transformation-induced hardening due to a dual-phase microstructure (BCC + HCP) in Ta x HfZrTi RHEAs. However, the yield strengths in studied alloys (TaHfZrTi, Ta 0.6 HfZrTi, Ta 0.5 HfZrTi, and Ta 0.4 HfZrTi) are dramatically decreased with an increase of interfaces (between BCC matrix and HCP phase) from 1356-354 MPa. In case of dual-phase HEAs, the strength tends to be improved by density of interfaces and massive solid-solution strengthening in the matrix, which stems from the distorted lattices [9]. From the previous study, one can conclude that the microcomposite-effect-induced hardening, which is associated with interface hardening between BCC and HCP phase in Ta x HfZrTi dual-phase microstructure, may not play a dominant role in strengthening. Furthermore, the level of lattice distortion in the matrix could be decreased by reduction of Ta contents, resulting in low yield strength in Ta 0.4 HfZrTi RHEA. Therefore, the mechanical stability with severe lattice distortion in matrix phase need to be further tailored by tuning the alloy compositions for overcoming the strength-ductility tradeoff in TRIP HEAs.

In this study, we attempted to apply a similar strategy (metastability-engineering) in TiZrHfV x Nb x Ta x (x = 1.0, 0.5, and 0.1) RHEAs (hereafter referred to as VNTx) for the further development of high strength and ductile TRIP RHEAs. The V and Nb were selected as the additional elements into previously studied composition (TaHfZrTi) [11] to enlarge the solid-solution strengthening effect (mainly caused by lattice distortion) in the matrix by increasing of constituent elements. Then, we gradually reduced the β-stabilizer elements (V, Nb, and Ta) to promote the strain-induced phase transformation for the plasticity of designed alloys. It is found that VNT0.1 RHEA exhibits a two-steps phase-transformations, (1) from BCC to orthorhombic α″ phase, and (2) BCC to HCP α′ or orthorhombic α″ to HCP α′ phase, according to the level of plastic deformation. Despite the VNT0.1 exhibited TRIP effects with large strain-hardening rate, the plasticity is a lower than that of other alloys, which have sufficient β-stabilizer elements (VNT0.5 and VNT1.0). This result could imply that the stress-induced phasetransformation during plastic-deformation is not beneficial to plasticity in TiZrHfV x Nb x Ta x BCC-structured RHEAs. As a result, the formation of dual-phase and phase transformation path during plasticdeformation could be important factors to achieve the ductility in RHEAs. Moreover, we further attempt to establish the TRIP HEAs design strategy, applying the Bo-Md approach. This newly developed HEA design strategy provides a road map to produce better materials for structural materials applications.

div.head: Experimental methods
div.p: The alloys ingots were prepared by using vacuum-arc-melting with high purity Ti, Zr, Hf, V, Nb, and Ta elements (99.95 wt% elemental purity) under a Ti-gettered high purity argon atmosphere. The ingots were re-melted more than 8 times for homogeneity and solidified on a water-cooled copper hearth. The as-cast rod samples were fabricated by suction casting into a cylindrical copper mold with 3 mm in diameter and 50 mm in length. The nominal compositions of alloys are listed in Table 1. Scanning-electron-microscopy (SEM) was conducted for analysis of the microstructure, using a TESCAN Mira LMH equipped with ZEISS YAG backscattered electron (BSE) detector and BRUKER X-Flash4010 energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) detector. Electron-backscattered-diffraction (EBSD) analysis was carried out using TSL Hikari Super EBSD Camera. The crystal structures of the as-cast and deformed specimens were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using Mini-Flex600 under Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54187 Å). Transmissionelectron-microscopy (TEM) was done for detailed microstructure inspection and phase identification using TECNAI F20 G2 TEM under 200 kV accelerating voltage. The thin specimens for TEM analysis were prepared by ion milling under liquid-nitrogen cooling. Compressive mechanical tests, using MTDI MINOS-100S, were performed on a cylindrical specimen with an aspect ratio of 2:1 (3 mm diameter and 6 mm length), at a strain rate of 1 × 10 -3 s -1 .

div.head: Results and discussion
div.p: 3.1. Phase identifications, microstructural investigations, and mechanical properties for as-cast TiZrHfV x Nb x Ta x (x = 1.0, 0.5 and 0.1) RHEAs Figure 1 shows the scanning-electron-microscopy (SEM) backscattered-electrons (BSE) images of the as-cast TiZrHfVxNbxTax (x = 1.0, 0.5, and 0.1) RHEAs. All present alloys consist of a typical dendritic microstructure, which is commonly observed from as-cast HEAs [12][13][14]. The different contrast between the dendritic (bright contrast) and interdendritic (dark contrast) regions is due to the chemical inhomogeneity. The detailed chemical compositions of dendritic (D) and interdendritic (ID) regions were verified by point EDS analysis, as listed in Table 1. The Nb, and Ta elements are distributed in dendritic region, while the interdendritic regions are enriched in Ti, Zr, and V for VNT1.0 alloy. In contrast, Ti and V are highly distributed in interdendritic regions, and the chemical compositions in dendritic regions are close to their nominal compositions for the VNT0.1 and VNT0.5. The enhancement of contrast between dendrites and interdendrites and reduction of dendritearm spacing with increase of V, Nb, and Ta elements is due to an increase of atomic-weight variation and change of melting temperature in different regions.

Figure 2 shows the XRD patterns of the as-cast VNTx (x = 1.0, 0.5, and 0.1) RHEAs. The XRD results indicate the formation of a single body-centered-cubic (BCC) phase in all alloys without presence of any secondary phases. The shifting of major BCC diffraction peak (110 peak) and increase of peak width with an increase of the V, Nb and Ta elements are clearly observed in Fig. 2(b). The lattice parameters of the alloys were calculated by fitting (110), (200), and (211) peaks in the XRD results. An averaged value with an error was obtained from these lattice parameters acquired from the three different peaks. The lattice constants of present RHEAs are 0.3358 ± 0.0004 nm, 0.3407 ± 0.0005 nm, and 0.3459 ± 0.0001 nm for VNT1.0, VNT0.5, and VNT0.1, respectively. The reduction of the lattice constant of the BCC phase caused by increase of solid solution of V, Nb, and Ta, which has relatively smaller atomic radius compared to principal elements (Ti Zr and Hf). The change of peak width could associate with increase of the variation of lattice constants between dendritic and interdendritic regions. The noticeable diffuse scattering was present in all the diffraction peaks, as indicated by the asymmetric peaks skewed toward the origin. The small hump on the left side of the peaks implies the overlapping of two peaks, which is attributed to the slightly-different lattice parameters between the dendrite and interdendrite regions. With increase of Nb, V, and Ti elements, the preferential distribution of a particular element in the dendrite and interdendrite regions becomes more significant and it is clearly reflected to XRD pattern with increase of peak width.

The mechanical properties and deformation behavior of the present RHEAs were investigated by uniaxial compression tests at room temperature. Fig. 3(a) presents the compressive true strainstress curves of the as-cast VNTx (x = 1.0, 0.5, and 0.1) RHEAs. The yield strength enhanced with an increase of V, Nb, and Ta contents (0.5 and 1.0 at. percentages). Moreover, VNT1.0 and VNT0.5 RHEAs show excellent room temperature plasticity with less strain-hardening behavior, compared to VNT0.1. Different with other alloys, the VNT0.1 exhibits a double yielding behavior, which is often observed in shape memory alloys as a stress-induced phase transformation, and relatively lower plasticity [15]. The values of yield strength and plastic strain for present RHEAs are summarized in Table 2. To further investigate the strain-hardening behaviors, the strain-hardening rate curves ( d d ) of the studied alloys are illustrated in Fig. 3(b). The VNT1.0 and VNT0.5 RHEAs indicates a maintenance of steady strain-hardening rate after sharp reduction at the elastic stage. In contrast, VNT0.1 shows a hump-like shape in the strain-hardening rate curve. The hardening-rate gradually increased during plastic deformation of ~ 17%, then it continuously dropped again.

The deformation mechanisms reflect to the shape of strainhardening rate curve, manifesting a monotonous reduction or nonmonotonous shapes (plateau or hump). The increase in the hardening rate usually arises from the stress/strain-induced phase transformation, whereas gradual reduction of strain-hardening rate is attributed to dislocation-slip-dominated plastic-deformation. The combination of dislocation-slip and stress/strain-induce phase transformation mechanisms result in plateau strain-hardening rate behavior [11,[16][17][18]. According to the fundamental understanding of strain-hardening analyses above, the dominant hardening mechanism in VNT1.0 and VNT0.5 RHEAs could be dislocation-slip at whole plastic deformation regions. On the other hand, the VNT0.1 alloy could have a transformation-induced hardening at early plastic stage, and it saturated after large plastic deformation of 17%.

div.head: Phase transformation in VNT0.1 RHEA during plastic deformation
div.p: To further investigate the stress/strain-induced phase transformation in VNT0.1 RHEA, the systematic XRD measurements performed, which are subjected to various strains (i.e., 5%, 10%, 15%, 20%, 25%, and 30%). As indicated in Fig. 4(a), the XRD patterns reveal that the BCC (β) phase gradually transformed to the HCP-type phase with an increase of strains. It should be noted that the BCC (β) phase was not transformed to HCP phase directly, but undergoes two-steps transformation sequences, as observed in the magnified XRD patterns in Fig. 4(b). When the VNT0.1 sample was applied by 5% strains, the orthorhombic-type (020) α″ and (021) α″ peaks appeared at 33.5° and 38.3°, respectively, and (002) α″ was split from (110) BCC . Further increase of the strains up to 10% results in the increase of the orthorhombic α″ peak intensities, indicating that the phase transformation from BCC to α″ could be responsible for the early plastic deformation. As further increase of strains over the 10%, the HCPtype (1010) α′ and (1011) α′ peaks presented near 33.2° and 37.9°, respectively, which reveals that the phase transformation from BCC (β) to HCP (α′) or orthorhombic (α″) to HCP (α′) at a large plastic deformation. Based on these systematic XRD results, it is clearly

div.head: Table 2
div.p: Yield strengths and plastic strains for TiZrHfV x Nb x Ta x (x = 1.0, 0.5, and 0.1) RHEAs. found that the degree of plastic strains strongly correlates to the evolution of the phase transformations in VNT0.1 RHEA, i.e., the small degree of plastic strain in the metastable BCC phase promotes the BCC to α″ first transformation, whereas the large amount of plastic strain leads to the significant distortion of metastable β or α″ lattices, which gives rise to the second transformation from BCC to α′ or α″ to α′ phase transformation. The phase transformation mechanisms in VNT0.1 RHEA during deformation can be explained by the Burgers mechanism with shear and atomic shuffles [19]. Fig. 4(c) shows the crystallographic unit cells for BCC (β), orthorhombic (α″), and HCP (α′) structures. When a compressive load applies on the alloy, lattice strains are concentrated in (110) BCC plane, i.e., tensile strain on < 110 > direction and compressive strain on < 001 > direction. Simultaneously, atoms on another (110) BCC plane shuffle to

[110] direction with {112} < 111 > shearing. These lattice strain processes induce the phase transformation from BCC to metastable α″ phase, which is an intermediate structure between BCC and HCP in the current study, as reflected by the XRD results on the 5 ~ 10% deformed samples. When further deformation applies on the alloy, the composed elements on {002} α″ planes shuffle to stable atomicsites, which leads to phase transformation from unstable α″ to more stable hexagonal α′ phase.

To provide visible evidence of strain-induced phase transformation in the VNT0.1 RHEA, EBSD phase mapping and TEM analyses were conducted for undeformed and 25%-deformed specimens. The undeformed sample [Fig. 5(a)] consists mostly of a BCC phase (98.2 vol%) with a small amount of HCP phase (1.8 vol%), which is in good agreement with the XRD result (Fig. 2). A bright-field TEM image in Fig. 5(b) shows a simple microstructure consisting of a BCC phase, confirmed by corresponding selected-area-electron-diffraction (SAED) pattern of zone axis of (110) BCC . The SAED pattern in Fig. 5(c) also reveals the presence of an athermal ω phase in the BCC matrix, which is often found in metastable beta-Ti alloys [20].

In contrast to the undeformed sample, the 25%-strained sample indicates that major composed phase is HCP and small amount of BCC phase presented along the grain boundary (Fig. 5(d)). The volume fraction of HCP phase is significantly increased from 1.8% to 85.4%. The microstructural evolution of the deformed specimen was also characterized by TEM, as shown in Fig. 5(e). Note that the TEM image was obtained from the middle of grain (denoted by a yellow box in the EBSD image), which reveals a typical martensitic morphology with bright and dark phases. Through the corresponding SAED patterns [Fig. 5(f) and (g)], the dark and bright contrast phases were identified as HCP (α′) with a space group of P63/mmc and orthorhombic (α″) with a space group of cmcm phases, respectively, and both phases have an orientation relationship of [2110] α″ // [210] α′ . It also indicates that presence of stress/strain-induced phase-transformation are not only α′, but also α″, which indicates the possible phase transformations from the BCC to HCP and orthorhombic to HCP during plastic-deformation.

Based on the in-depth studies of deformation behaviors in VNT0.1 RHEA, including the strain-hardening and phase- transformation behaviors, it is worth nothing that the stress-induced phase transformation from BCC to HCP during plastic deformation is not beneficial to ductility. In contrast, the VNT1.0 RHEA shows higher plasticity and yield strength compared to VNT0.1. The 300 MPa enhanced yield strength in VNT1.0 RHEA is associate with solid-solution strengthening effects in BCC matrix, which stems from severe lattice distortion with an increase of V, Nb, and Ta elements. The strengthening by lattice distortion in present RHEAs was quantitatively estimated by the formula, which has been suggested by Senkov et al. [23]. The determined strengthening by lattice distortion in dendritic and interdendritic regions indicates that the difference between VNT0.1 and VNT0.5 (235.2 MPa for dendritic and 230.77 MPa for interdendritic) is much larger than VNT0.5 and VNT1.0 HEA (58.5 MPa for dendritic and 76.7 MPa for interdendritic), which is in good agreement with the trend of yield strength. In fact, the previously reported Ta 0.4 HfZrTi RHEA indicates significantly improved ductility through the stress/strain-induced phase-transformation from destabilized-BCC to HCP phase. However, the Ta 0.4 HfZrTi RHEA consists of dual phase (combination of BCC and HCP) in undeformed sample, which is different feature compared to that of current RHEAs (VNT0.1 consists of single BCC phase).

The VNT0.1 RHEA shows a stepwise phase-transformation behavior, (1) β to α″, (2) β to α′ or α″ to α′ according to the level of plastic deformation. The microstructural evolutions with stepwise phase-transformation were schematically illustrated in Fig. 5(h). First, the metastable BCC grains are elastically deformed until reaching the yield stress (no phase transformation). When the loads are further applied above the yielding, the plastic-deformation begins with the dislocation slips, which promotes the strain-induced β to α″ first transformation. Sequantly, further deformations could induce the β to α′ or α″ to α′ phase-transformation. The stepwise phase-transformation has been observed in Ti based alloys [21], while the most TRIP RHEAs exhibit single phase-transformation (i.e. β to α″ or β to α′) [11,16,17,22]. These results can imply that the TRIP deformation mechanism could be dependent upon the alloying elements. Finally, these phase-transformation gives rise to the formation of a high density of phase boundaries, which is responsible for the intensive strain-hardening behavior of the current RHEAs, as reported in TRIP based alloys [23,24]. As a result, the phase compositions and transformation paths during plastic-deformations could be considerable factors to develop the ductile RHEAs with conventional TRIP effects.

div.head: Alloy design strategy for development of ductile HEAs
div.p: Despite of extensive efforts to develop the ductile RHEAs, which is induced by phase-transformation, limited HEAs systems have been studied due to the lack of TRIP HEAs design strategies. Hence, it is essential to develop the concrete TRIP HEAs design strategy for further investigating the correlation between phase-transformation paths and plasticity in BCC structure RHEAs. One of powerful and convenient methods to design the TRIP HEAs is the "d-electron alloy" strategy, which utilizes two electronic parameters, Bo (the covalent bond strength among the alloying elements) and Md (the mean or- bital energy level concerning electronegativity and elements radius), which can be calculated by DV-Xα molecular orbital method [25]. This approach has been often employed for designing TRIP Ti-alloys to predict phase stability and deformation behaviors, calculating average values of Bo and Md based on the chemical compositions [25]. The Bo and Md values of the alloy can be obtained from fol- lowing equations:
div.formula: = = Bo X Bo •( ) i n i i 1 (1) = = Md X Md •( ) i n i i 1 (2)
div.p: where X i is the atomic fraction of the i th element in the alloy, Bo ( ) i and Md ( ) i are respective values for the i th element, as summarized in Table 3 [25]. The calculated Bo Md parameters of designed alloys can be plotted to Bo Md diagram, as presented in Fig. 6. The Bo Md concept has been well adopted and established based on various TRIP Ti-alloy systems, which are located in less than 2.6 of Md and less than 2.94 of Bo (marked region in blue). The reported RHEA systems are settled in upper regions (marked region in red) of Bo Md diagram. This is due to the large and various values of Bo and Md for refractory elements. In present work, we aim to design TRIP HEAs via the adjustment of Bo Md parameters. The positions corresponding to the chemical compositions of the designed alloys in Bo Md diagram are displayed in Fig. 6. The Ti, Zr, and Hf have a relatively low Bo and high Md values, thus the position of the TiZrHf equi-molar ternary alloy can be located around the α region in the Bo Md diagram, showing the more preferentially formed the HCP phase. In contrast, the addition of the V, Nb, and Ta elements is expected to move the position to the β-stable region in the Bo Md diagram, since these elements possess relatively large values of Bo and small values of Md. Note that the M s =RT line in the Bo Md diagram is extension of the line, which predicts the martensite formation starting at room temperature, and can be considered as destabilized phase area associated with occurrence of the phase transformation during deformation [16]. The VNT0.1 RHEA, which is located close to the M s =RT line, exhibits the stress/strain-induced phase transformation from the BCC (β) phase to hexagonal (α′) and/ or orthorhombic (α″) phases during deformation with considerable strain-hardening. On the other hand, the VNT0.5 and VNT1.0 are located in β-stable region, which is in good agreement with experimental observation in previous section. Previously reported TRIP RHEAs, such as Ti 35 Zr 27.5 Hf 27.5 Nb 5 Ta 5 and Nb x HfZrTi are also included in Bo Md diagram [11,16,17,22], indicating they are all lo- cated near the M s =RT line. With the trends of Bo Md diagram, it can be concluded that the Bo and Md are the importantly con- siderable factors to design the TRIP HEAs. Moreover, this newly developed HEAs design strategy facilitates the efficient TRIP HEAs design.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In present work, the TiZrHfV x Nb x Ta x (x = 1.0, 0.5, and 0.1) RHEAs have been designed and developed by applying the metastabilityengineering alloy design strategy [9,11]. The V, Nb, and Ta were selected as the additional elements into TiZrHf alloy to enhance the strength and plasticity through the solid-solution strengthening effect (which mainly stems from lattice distortion), work hardening effect, and stress/strain-induced phase transformation. To understand the deformation/transformation behavior at room temperature, the deformed TiZrHfV 0.1 Nb 0.1 Ta 0.1 alloy was systematically investigated by XRD, EBSD, and TEM. The main conclusions are:

1. All studied as-cast RHEAs, TiZrHfV x Nb x Ta x (x = 1.0, 0.5, and 0.1), possess typical dendritic microstructure and formation of single BCC solid-solution phase. However, stress-strain curves results indicate that the VNT1.0 and VNT0.5 RHEAs have high yield strength and excellent room temperature plasticity with less strain-hardening behavior. The VNT0.1 exhibits a double yielding behavior with significant strain-hardening behavior, which is often observed in shape memory alloys as a stress-induced phase transformation, and relatively lower plasticity 2. According to the strain-hardening rate analyses, the dominant deformation mechanism for VNT1.0 and VNT0.5 RHEAs could be dislocation-slip at whole plastic deformation regions. In contrast, the VNT0.1 alloy could have a transformation-induced hardening at early plastic stage, and it saturated after large plastic deformation of 17%. 3. The deformation behaviors in VNT0.1 RHEA were further investigated by systematic XRD measurements, EBSD and TEM. These in-depth studies show that the VNT0.1 RHEA exhibits a two-steps phase-transformations, (1) from BCC to orthorhombic α″ phase, and (2) BCC to HCP α′ or orthorhombic α″ to HCP α′ phase, according to the level of plastic deformation. 4. Despite the VNT0.1 exhibited stress/strain-induced phase transformation with large strain-hardening rate, the plasticity is a lower than that of other alloys (VNT0.5 and VNT1.0, which have sufficient β-stabilizer elements). In conclusions, the phase components (dual-phase) and phase transformation path during plastic-deformation could be important factors to achieve the ductility in RHEAs. 5. Based on present work and other reported TRIP HEA compositions, the new TRIP HEAs design strategy was established by applying the Bo Md approach. This newly developed HEA de- sign strategy provides a road map to produce ductile HEAs for structural materials applications.

div.head: CRediT authorship contribution statement
div.p: Yunjong Jung, Kangjin Lee, Chanho Lee and Gian Song performed the scanning-electron-microscopy, electron back-scattered diffraction Xray diffraction, and mechanical tests. Yunjong Jung, Chanho Lee, and Gian Song. wrote the main manuscript. Soon Jik Hong, Jin Kyu Lee, Junhee Han, Peter K. Liaw, and Ki Buem Kim mainly contributed to the transmission-electron-microscopy experiments and revision of manuscript. All authors discussed the results and implications and commented on the manuscript at all stages.

div.head: Declaration of Competing Interest
div.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

analytic.title: Refractory highentropy alloys
Enhanced mechanical properties of HfMoTaTiZr and HfMoNbTaTiZr refractory high-entropy alloys
Structure and mechanical properties of a light-weight AlNbTiV high entropy alloy
A precipitation-hardened high-entropy alloy with outstanding tensile properties

A TRIP-assisted dual-phase high-entropy alloy: grain size and phase fraction effects on deformation behavior
Ultrastrong ductile and stable high-entropy alloys at small scales
Metastable high-entropy dualphase alloys overcome the strength-ductility trade-off
